energy, not mass.   mass would be continnuity equation
@Randomkloud  but how mass is not conserved in this case.

@manmohanbisht69  mass is also conserved, look at the derivation of Bernoulli's equation by van Biezen (on youtube) and you will see how mass is left out because it is conserved. Bernoulli's equation represents the change in potential energy and change in kinetic energy which is a constant (because mass in the system is conserved we can asssume there is a constant amount of mass in the system which reqiures a constant amount of work to flow.)  in simple terms, continuity equation describes the conservation of mass, and bernoulli equation describes the conservation of energy. Both are conserved.
@Randomkloud  what about momentum. Can we say energy, mass and momentum all three are conserved in Bernoulli principle..

I tried it so many times but still came up with the same answer which is 7.6 m/s. It should be less then V1 which is 5.75 m/s.  Water is flowing through a pipe of two circular cross-sectional area A1 and A2 lying at a height difference of 25 cm. The pressure difference between the two cross-sectional areas A1 and A2 is 15000 Pa. If the velocity of water through the cross-section A1 is 5.75 m/s, what would be the velocity of the water through the cross-section A2?  Thanks!
very helpful
yes i have the same question, for the last problem
But I think that the speed is the most important factor since the speed increases when the pressure decreases and vice versa
Because of decrease in velocity.

Pressure increases with decease in velocity. Pressure decreases with increase in Velocity. Increase in Area decreases velocity henceforth increasing Pressure. Decrease in area increases velocity henceforth decrease in pressure. Get it now😂
Conservation of energy

Are you sure you are thinking correctly about the problem? Make sure that you're taking into account if there is an increase in height or a decrease between points A and B. If you already know that the velocity should be less at point A than at point B, and we assume that both cross section areas measure the same, then we can can assume that the change in velocity is ony dependant on a change in pressure. Now, we know that if the speed decreases, then the pressure increases. And if the pressure increases, it is because the height decreases. So it would make sense to assume a dip of 25 cm (0.25 m) from point A to point B.  So we know this:   Area A = Area B v2 < v1 P2 = P1 + 15000pa h (height)1 = 0.25m h2 = 0 rho water (we will use R) = 997 kg/m^3 We use Bernoulli's equation:    P1 + (0.5*R*(v1^2)) + Rgh1 = P1 + 15000 + (0.5*R*(v2^2)) + Rgh2   (0.5*R*(v1^2)) + Rgh = 15000 + (0.5*R*(v2^2)) + 0   Isolate v2:   sqrt( 2/R * ( (997*5.75^2)/2 + (997*9.8*0.25) - 15000) = v2   v2 = 2.806 m/s < 5.75 m/s

Rida Arshad in a closed system there is no flow rate, therefore it couldn’t work

Rida Arshad  Hydrostatics and Bernoulli Principle Teaching Notes Search domain www.brown.edu/Departments/Engineering/Courses/en3-Advanced/Hydrostatics and Bernoulli Principle Slide Notes.pdf expansion or contractions require extra terms to make Bernoulli's equation valid. 24.No shaft work - Because the Bernoulli equation is based on the conservation of energy in a closed system, extra work added to the fluid negates the balance of the Bernoulli equation.
